subject: Personal Finance
title: Loss Aversion
description: A quick win: understand Loss Aversion.

hook.text: Losing $100 hurts about twice as much as gaining $100 feels good. We're wired to avoid losses.

buildup.text: Psychologists Kahneman and Tversky proved this asymmetry in the 1970s. It shapes every financial decision.

discovery.text: Loss aversion makes investors hold losing stocks too long, hoping to avoid realizing the loss.

twist.text: It also makes us sell winners too quickly â€” we grab gains before they can disappear.

climax.text: The pain of loss doesn't just affect stocks. It drives insurance purchases, negotiations, and career choices.

punchline.text: We fear loss more than we desire gain.

quiz.question: What is loss aversion?
options: Losses feel roughly twice as painful as equivalent gains feel good
A strategy to avoid risky investments
